text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full‐page historiated miniature occupying the upper three quarters of the folio, enclosed in a tall gothic architectural frame with foliate vine‐scrolls in the margins. Below the image is a two‐line rubricated caption in red and blue ink. The illumination dominates the page, with the text confined to a small block at the foot.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata book hand with red rubrics, professional execution, frequent ligatures and abbreviations

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for halos, architectural frames and decorative diaper patterns; ultramarine underlies the upper background tapestry; vermilion dominates the castle masonry and clerical robes; white highlights layered over pigments for drapery folds; green used sparingly for vine scrolls and water; overall palette well-preserved with minimal pigment loss.

features: Two‐tier register: upper investiture scene and lower castle exterior/interiors
Central bishop and kneeling figure emphasized by raised platform
Diagonal gesture of attendants directs gaze toward central action
Symmetrical twin towers framing lower register

decorative_elements: Gothic micro-architecture frame with pinnacles and crockets
Marginal vine scrolls with naturalistic ivy leaves
Diapered gold background in upper register
Polychrome diaper pattern on lower interior walls

drawing_technique.line_style: Firm quill pen outlines in dark brown ink with varying weight for figures and architecture
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle tonal modulation by layering pigments and lead-white highlights; limited incised shading lines
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without true linear perspective; overlapping registers and figures create spatial suggestion

content_theme.scene_description: In the single, dominant investiture scene, a bishop wearing a pink-trimmed chasuble and gold mitre stands on a crenellated platform within a red-brick crenellated hall. He holds a crozier in his left hand and places a ring or baton on the right hand of a kneeling layman dressed in a blue surcoat over chain mail. To the bishop’s right, three clerics in red and blue albs look on; to his left, two armed knights stand with visored helmets and swords. The upper scene background is patterned in burnished gold and ultramarine diaper, and the floor is black with white highlights. Below, a two-storey castle façade with twin round towers rises from a green-blue river. Inside the lower register’s three compartments, small figures enact domestic or administrative activities: a scribe at a desk, a steward weighing coin, and a seated figure in council. To the right, a boat drifts on the water with a reclining passenger. All figures are drawn with fine line work, their garments articulated by white highlights and minimal hatching.

religious: Bishop in pink-trimmed gold chasuble, mitre and crozier
Three assisting clerics in red and blue albs
secular: Kneeling nobleman in blue surcoat and chain mail
Two standing knights in visored helmets and swords
Boatman guiding a small craft in the river

architectural: Red brick castle with crenellations and twin round towers
natural: Foliate vine scrolls with ivy leaves

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, finely scraped and pumiced to a smooth surface; quire structure suggests quaternion gatherings; consistent margins c. 45 × 30 mm.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments vibrant with minimal fading; slight flaking of vermilion in high points; minor cockling at folio edges; evidence of early modern reinforcement in lower margin.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in frame areas
UV‐visible brown ink underdrawing beneath key figures
Regular ruling in plummet for text and image alignment
Punchwork in gold backgrounds creating diamond motifs

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Clerical or monastic community for psalter recitation

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This richly illuminated page, opening the Psalter with the large initials “PS,” was likely produced in a high‐end Paris workshop around 1320–1330, reflecting the height of Gothic illumination in northern France. Its combination of hierarchical composition, sumptuous ultramarine and gold, and delicate foliate marginalia aligns with the Deux Ponts corpus, which catered to aristocratic patrons seeking both devotional functionality and visual spectacle. The investiture scene foregrounds the intersection of ecclesiastical and secular power: the bishop bestows authority on a kneeling layman, reinforcing the mutual reinforcement of religious sanction and feudal hierarchy. Architecturally, the depiction of a two‐storey crenellated castle with interior vignettes underscores the era’s interest in realistic settings, even within the flat pictorial space governed by hierarchical scaling. Technically, the use of raised gesso beneath gold leaf and finely stippled punchwork reveals a collaborative workshop employing multiple hands—likely a master illuminator for figures and a specialist for borders. Iconographically, the absence of overt biblical reference transforms the Psalter frontispiece into a statement of patronal identity, marrying personal commemoration with liturgical purpose. Comparative analysis with the Épinal and Paris Master of the Bible Historiale suggests shared stylistic traits—particularly in facial types and drapery treatment—yet this page exhibits unique innovations in register layering and narrative integration. Thus, the illumination navigates between traditional devotional imagery and emerging courtly tastes, embodying the transitional aesthetics of early 14th‐century Parisian illumination.
